title: The Long Loneliness: The Autobiography of Dorothy Day
description:
This inspiring and fascinating memoir, subtitled, Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Autobiography of the Legendary Catholic Social Activist,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ The Long Loneliness is the late Dorothy DayÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s compelling autobiographical testament to her life of social activism and her spiritual pilgrimage. A founder of the Catholic Worker Movement and longtime associate of Peter Maurin, Dorothy Day was eulogized in the New York Times as, Ã¢â‚¬Å“a nonviolent social radical of luminous personality.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ The Long Loneliness recounts her remarkable journey from the Greenwich Village political and literary scene of the 1920s through her conversion to Catholicism and her lifelong struggle to help bring about Ã¢â‚¬Å“the kind of society where it is easier to be good.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½


--About the Author--

Dorothy Day (1897 Ã¢â‚¬â€œ 1980) was an American journalist, social activist and devout Catholic convert. In 1933, with Peter Maurin, she established the Catholic Worker, creating a community dedicated to direct aid for the poor and homeless, solidarity with the dispossessed, and social change. Day participated in the labor struggles of the 1930s, the Civil Rights movement, and nonviolent, pacifist opposition to WWII, Vietnam and Cold War militarism, and her cause for canonization is open in the Catholic Church.

Robert Ellsberg was part of the Catholic Worker community in New York City for the last five years of Dorothy DayÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s life (1975-80), and served for two years as managing editor of The Catholic Worker. He has also edited Dorothy Day: Selected Writings and All the Way to Heaven: The Selected Letters of Dorothy Day, and is the author of All Saints.
